awd_titl_txt: Lipoic acid biosynthesis: understanding sulfur attachment to aliphatic carbon centers
awd_abstract_narration:
The mechanisms by which enzymes attach sulfur atoms to inert carbon centers are poorly understood despite the importance of these reactions in cellular metabolism and maintenance. One such sulfur-containing molecule of great importance is lipoic acid, an eight-carbon straight-chain fatty acid (octanoic acid) that has one sulfur atom appended to carbon 6 (C6) and one sulfur atom appended to carbon 8 (C8). It is used as a cofactor in several large protein complexes that are involved in energy production and storage, as well as in the metabolism of several amino acids. Despite the relatively detailed understanding of how lipoic acid functions in these complexes, it biosynthesis has been puzzling due to the limited understanding of how sulfur atoms are appended onto aliphatic carbon centers. This research seeks to assess the source of the appended sulfur atoms in this important sulfur-containing molecule and the mechanism of its biosynthesis.  This project might provide a new paradigm for this type of chemistry for a large spectrum of C-S bond formation processes in metabolism.  Outreach activities to encourage participation of underrepresented minority students in the STEM disciplines will be conducted.

This project focuses at the intersection of iron-sulfur cluster and lipoic acid biosynthesis and aims at providing a detailed molecular understanding of how aliphatic carbon centers are functionalized with sulfur atoms. Experiments have shown that a protein called NfuA, which itself is an iron-sulfur protein, can reinsert or repair the degraded auxiliary cluster on lipoyl synthase (LipA) after each turnover. In turn, NfuA obtains its cluster via a complex pathway by which iron-sulfur clusters are biosynthesized and trafficked. The aims of this project focus on elucidating the detailed mechanism that govern how the cluster on NfuA is transferred to LipA. Mössbauer spectroscopy and mass spectrometry will be used to follow iron and sulfur transfer, respectively. Protein crystallography will be used to monitor selenium transfer from NfuA containing a [4Fe-4Se] cluster to LipA, and efforts will be made to obtain structures of the NfuA/LipA complex. Lastly, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, as well as protein film voltammetry, will be used to study the unique serine ligation to the auxiliary cluster and to determine why it is critical for the reaction of LipA.  

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Lipoyl synthase (LipA) catalyzes the last step in the biosynthesis of the lipoyl cofactor, which is the attachment of two sulfhydryl groups to C6 and C8 of a pendant octanoyl chain located on a lipoyl carrier protein (LCP). The enzyme is a member of the radical S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) superfamily, meaning that it uses SAM as a precursor to a 5’-deoxyadenosyl 5’-radical (5’-dA•), which abstracts hydrogen atoms from C6 and C8 to allow for subsequent attachment of sulfur atoms. One of the major questions in the field has been “What is the direct source of the appended sulfur atoms?” In a series of papers using quantitative, spectroscopic, and X-ray crystallographic techniques, we showed that, unlike most radical SAM (RS) enzymes, which contain one [Fe4S4] cluster, lipoyl synthase contains two [Fe4S4] clusters, one of which, the auxiliary cluster, is degraded during turnover to provide the appended sulfur atoms. This unique mechanism has been controversial in the field because it means that the enzyme is inactivated after only one turnover due to the loss of its auxiliary iron-sulfur (Fe/S) cluster. 

 

The main objective of the studies supported by this grant was to understand how the auxiliary cluster is reinstated after each turnover, with a particular focus on the process in Escherichia coli. We identified several proteins that can reinstate the Fe/S cluster (NfuA, ErpA, and IscU), and focused particularly on NfuA, an intermediate Fe/S cluster carrier protein. Our rationale for focusing on NfuA was derived from studies in human patients that found that defects in the gene that encodes NFU1, a homolog of NfuA, caused fatal deficiencies in enzymes that use the lipoyl cofactor. We showed that NfuA can transfer its Fe/S cluster to LipA to reinstall a full auxiliary cluster or repair the auxiliary during turnover, which renders LipA catalytic. We also showed that this cluster transfer does not limit the rate of catalysis. 

 

In addition to our studies on E. coli LipA, we isolated and characterized the human enzyme, which is denoted as LIAS. We showed using in vitro reactions that NFU1, like NfuA, can restore the auxiliary Fe/S cluster of LIAS during turnover. Additional studies focused on a completely new pathway for generating the lipoyl cofactor, which is found in certain archaea and bacteria. This pathway uses two proteins (LipS1 and LipS2) rather than one. We showed that LipS2 first catalyzes sulfur attachment at C8, while LipS1 catalyzes sulfur attachment at C6. Both LipS1 and LipS2 had been annotated as biotin synthases. However, unlike biotin synthase, which contains an [Fe2S2] cluster and an [Fe4S4] cluster, we showed that both LipS1 and LipS2 contain two [Fe4S4] clusters.

 

Studies were also conducted on MiaB, a protein that catalyzes the attachment of a methylthio (–SCH3) group at C2 position of N6-(isopentenyl)adenosine (i6A) in the final step of the biosynthesis of the tRNA nucleotide 2-methythio-N6-(isopentenyl)adenosine (ms2i6A). Like LipA, MiaB is an RS enzyme that harbors an auxiliary [Fe4S4] cluster in addition to the radical SAM [Fe4S4] cluster. The sulfur atom in the methylthio group has been shown to derive ultimately from cysteine, while the methyl moiety of the methylthio group is derived from SAM. In the first step of the reaction, we showed that SAM donates a methyl group to one of the sulfide ions of the auxiliary [Fe4S4] cluster, resulting in the loss of an iron ion and the formation of an [Fe3S4] cluster. In the second step, an intact methylthio group is transferred to the substrate in a radical-mediated process.  We were able to capture each step of the reaction mechanism by X-ray crystallography. In the SAM-bound structure, the methyl moiety of SAM is 3.4 Å from a sulfur atom of the [Fe3S4] auxiliary cluster. Interestingly, in the structure with substrate and 5’-deoxyadenosine and methionine, the products of the reductive cleavage of SAM, the 5’-carbon of 5’-deoxyadenosine and a sulfur atom of the [Fe3S4] auxiliary cluster are on opposite sides of C2 of i6A and at an angle that suggests that the C2 carbon undergoes a change in hybridization from sp2- to sp3-hybridized during the reaction. This change in hybridization is believed to be influenced by a conserved arginine residue that hydrogen bonds to N3 of i6A through a water molecule and the attack of the sulfur atom of the cluster-bound methylthio group onto C2. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

In addition to the impact of the science, wherein our studies provided the first glimpse of how Fe/S clusters can be used as substrates in enzymatic reactions, this project served as the basis for the training of two African American undergraduate students and one Caucasian first-generation student, all of whom are currently in graduate school or preprofessional school. Moreover, the results of these studies were disseminated at several conferences and universities and at retreats for training grants in chemical biology.

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Squire J Booker
